A remote user can also conduct a portscan against port 14247 to cause the IBM Director Agent process (twgipc.exe) to consume 100% of the CPU.  A reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.  Director Agent versions 2.2 and 3.11 are reportedly affected.  Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCed23357 to this flaw.

The following IBM server model numbers are reportedly affected: IBM X330 (8654 or 8674), IBM X340, IBM X342, IBM X345, MCS-7815-1000, MCS-7815I-2.0, MCS-7835I-2.4, and MCS-7835I-3.0.  Operating system (OS) versions prior to OS 2000.2.6 on the IBM servers are vulnerable.
Impact':
A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.

A remote user can cause the CPU utilization to reach 100%.
Solution: The vendor reports that this vulnerability can be resolved by making configuration changes.  Cisco is providing a repair script to close the vulnerable ports and configure the Director Agent in a secure state.  No upgrade is required.

Title: Cisco IP Interactive Voice Response Default Configuration on IBM Servers Grants Administrative Access to Remote Users
Version(s): Systems on IBM Hardware with OS version prior to OS 2000.2.6
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco IP Interactive Voice Response (IP IVR) when installed on IBM servers.  A remote user can gain administrative access to the system.  A remote user can also cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Cisco reported that the default installation of several Cisco voice products on the IBM platform leaves the Director Agent configured in an unsecure state.  As a result, a remote user can conduct denial of service attacks or gain administrative access.

The report indicates that a remote user can connect to port 14247 and gain administrative access without having to authenticate.  Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCed33037 to this flaw.

A remote user can also conduct a portscan against port 14247 to cause the IBM Director Agent process (twgipc.exe) to consume 100% of the CPU.  A reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.  Director Agent versions 2.2 and 3.11 are reportedly affected.  Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCed23357 to this flaw.

The following IBM server model numbers are reportedly affected: IBM X330 (8654 or 8674), IBM X340, IBM X342, IBM X345, MCS-7815-1000, MCS-7815I-2.0, MCS-7835I-2.4, and MCS-7835I-3.0.  Operating system (OS) versions prior to OS 2000.2.6 on the IBM servers are vulnerable.
Impact':
A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.

A remote user can cause the CPU utilization to reach 100%.
Solution: The vendor reports that this vulnerability can be resolved by making configuration changes.  Cisco is providing a repair script to close the vulnerable ports and configure the Director Agent in a secure state.  No upgrade is required.

Title: Cisco CallManager Default Configuration on IBM Servers Grants Administrative Access to Remote Users
Version(s): Systems on IBM Hardware with OS version prior to OS 2000.2.6
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco CallManager when installed on IBM servers.  A remote user can gain administrative access to the system.  A remote user can also cause denial of service conditions on the target system.
Cisco reported that the default installation of several Cisco voice products on the IBM platform leaves the Director Agent configured in an unsecure state.  As a result, a remote user can conduct denial of service attacks or gain administrative access.

The report indicates that a remote user can connect to port 14247 and gain administrative access without having to authenticate.  Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCed33037 to this flaw.

A remote user can also conduct a portscan against port 14247 to cause the IBM Director Agent process (twgipc.exe) to consume 100% of the CPU.  A reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.  Director Agent versions 2.2 and 3.11 are reportedly affected.  Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCed23357 to this flaw.

The following IBM server model numbers are reportedly affected: IBM X330 (8654 or 8674), IBM X340, IBM X342, IBM X345, MCS-7815-1000, MCS-7815I-2.0, MCS-7835I-2.4, and MCS-7835I-3.0.  Operating system (OS) versions prior to OS 2000.2.6 on the IBM servers are vulnerable.
Impact':
A remote user can gain administrative access to the application.

A remote user can cause the CPU utilization to reach 100%.
Solution: The vendor reports that this vulnerability can be resolved by making configuration changes.  Cisco is providing a repair script to close the vulnerable ports and configure the Director Agent in a secure state.  No upgrade is required.

Title: Cisco BTS 10200 Softswitch H.323 Processing Flaws Let Remote Users Deny Service
Version(s): Cisco BTS 10200 Softswitch; prior to version 4.1
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco BTS 10200 Softswitch in the processing of H.323 messages. A remote user can cause the target system to crash and reboot by sending malformed H.323/H.225 packets.
Cisco reported that several Cisco products have vulnerabilities in the processing of H.323 messages. The University of Oulu H.323 protocol test suite was used to identify these flaws.

A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system. The target system may crash and reboot.

Cisco has assigned BugID CSCea48755 to this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash and reboot.
Solution: Cisco has issued a fixed version (4.1) of the BTS 10200 Softswitch.

Title: Cisco Internet Service Node H.323 Processing Flaws Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in the Cisco Internet Service Node in the processing of H.323 messages. A remote user can cause the target system to crash and reboot or to hang by sending malformed H.323/H.225 packets.
Cisco reported that several Cisco products have vulnerabilities in the processing of H.323 messages.  The University of Oulu H.323 protocol test suite was used to identify these flaws.

A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.  The target system may crash and reboot.  On the Cisco Internet Service Node, a remote user can reportedly cause the system to crash or to hang with processor utilization of 100% (preventing new calls, possibly dropping existing calls, and requiring a reboot to return to normal operations).
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash and reboot or to hang. If the system hangs, CPU utilization will reach 100% and a manual reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
Cisco does not plan to issue a software fix.  The vendor has described a workaround in their advisory, available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20040113-h323.shtml#workarounds

Title: Cisco Conference Connection H.323 Processing Flaws Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in the Cisco Conference Connection in the processing of H.323 messages. A remote user can cause the target system to crash and reboot or to hang by sending malformed H.323/H.225 packets.
Cisco reported that several Cisco products have vulnerabilities in the processing of H.323 messages.  The University of Oulu H.323 protocol test suite was used to identify these flaws.

A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the target system.  The target system may crash and reboot.  On the Cisco Conference Connection, a remote user can reportedly cause the system to crash or to hang with processor utilization of 100% (preventing new calls, possibly dropping existing calls, and requiring a reboot to return to normal operations).
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash and reboot or to hang. If the system hangs, CPU utilization will reach 100% and a manual reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
Cisco does not plan to issue a software fix.  The vendor has described a workaround in their advisory, available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20040113-h323.shtml#workarounds

Title: Cisco CallManager H.323 Processing Flaws Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in the Cisco CallManager in the processing of H.323 messages.  A remote user can cause the target system to crash and reboot or to hang by sending malformed H.323/H.225 packets.
Cisco reported that several Cisco products have vulnerabilities in the processing of H.323 messages.  The University of Oulu H.323 protocol test suite was used to identify these flaws.

On the Cisco CallManager, a remote user can reportedly cause the target system to crash or to hang with processor utilization of 100% (preventing new calls, possibly dropping existing calls, and requiring a reboot to return to normal operations).

Cisco CallManager systems running 3.1 or 3.2 are vulnerable only if the IP address of the originating device is configured as a H.323 gateway, H.323 client, or intercluster trunk on the CallManager or if "Allow Anonymous Calls" is enabled in the gatekeeper section of the CallManager configuration, according to the vendor.  

Cisco reports that the CallManager (3.1, 3.2) will close any TCP sessions containing H.323 messages from a device that is not configured as an H.225.0 device.

Cisco CallManager 3.3 is vulnerable regardless of the above configuration settings.

Cisco has assigned Bug IDs CSCdx82831, CSCea46545, and CSCea55518 to these flaws.
Impact': A remote user can cause the system to crash and reboot or to hang.  If the system hangs, CPU utilization will reach 100% and a manual reboot is required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution: Cisco has issued a fix in releases 3.1(4b)spD, 3.2(3), 3.3(2)spC, and 3.3(3) and later releases.

Title: sipd Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in sipd.  A remote user can cause the target service to crash.
SecuriTeam reported that a flaw in the 'tp/tp.c' file allows a remote user to send a specially crafted SIP request to cause the target sipd daemon to crash.

According to the report, the software does not properly validate the return value of the gethostbyname_r() function.  A remote user can cause the function to return a value that is not properly handled by the code, the report said.  This can reportedly be achieved, for example, by causing the code to attempt to resolve a non-existant hostname (such as 'A192.168.1.6').

A demonstration exploit script is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the sipd process to crash.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (0.1.4), available at:

http://www.sxdesign.com/download/sipd-0.1.4.tar.bz2

Title: Speak Freely Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Spoofed Packets or a Malformed GIF File
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in Speak Freely.  A remote user can cause the service to crash.
Luigi Auriemma reported that a remote user can send UDP packets with spoofed source addresses to the target system to cause the application to crash.  Approximately 160 packets may cause some systems to crash (observed on a Windows 98SE system), according to the report.  A demonstration exploit script is available at:

http://aluigi.altervista.org/poc/sfdos.zip

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted GIF image file for the "Show your face" feature to cause the target system to crash.  If the GIF has image width and height header values that are set to zero or are too large, a GlobalAlloc() function call will fail and the application will crash, the report said.

Only the Windows-based version is affected by these denial of service flaws.

Some demonstration exploit steps are provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the target user's Speak Freely application to crash.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that you can disable the option "Show faces of other users" from the "Options -> Show your face" menu to avoid the GIF-related denial of service vulnerability.

[Editor's note:  The vendor has issued an End of Life Announcement for Speak Freely, indicating that version 7.6a will be the last release of the product.  The announcement is available at: http://www.fourmilab.ch/speakfree/eol/]

Title: Asterisk PBX Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Inject SQL Commands via CallerID
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Asterisk PBX software.  A remote user can inject SQL commands to gain access to the system.
@stake reported that a remote user can set a specially crafted CallerID string to inject SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database.  The flaw reportedly resides in the Call Detail Record (CDR) logging function.  The software does not properly validate CDR data, the report said.

A remote user can exploit this flaw via a voice-over-IP (VoIP) connection or via the telephone network.

The vendor was reportedly notified on August 17, 2003.

[Editor's note: @stake does not permit redistribution of their advisories. The original advisory is available at: http://www.atstake.com/research/advisories/2003/a091103-1.txt]
Impact': A remote user can inject arbitrary SQL commands to be executed by the underlying database server.
Solution: The vendor has issued a fix in the CVS version (as of September 9, 2003).

Title: Asterisk 'chan_sip.c' SIP Message Buffer Overflow Lets Remote Users Gain Access to the System
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A buffer overflow vulnerability was reported in the Asterisk PBX software in the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) implementation.  A remote user can gain access to the target system, potentially with root privileges.
@stake Inc. reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted SIP request 1024 bytes in length with a particular request type (MESSAGE or INFO type) to trigger a buffer overflow and execute arbitrary code.  The code will run with the privileges of the user that started the Asterisk process, which is reported to be 'root' user privileges in the default installation.

According to the report, neither the MESSAGE nor the INFO type SIP packets require authentication.  A remote user can thus gain access to the target system.

The flaw reportedly resides in the 'chan_sip.c' file in the get_msg_text() function.

The vendor was reportedly notified on August 15, 2003.

[Editor's note:  @stake does not permit redistribution of their advisories.  The original advisory is available at:  http://www.atstake.com/research/advisories/2003/a090403-1.txt]
Impact': A remote user can execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the Asterisk service (reported to be root privileges in the default installation).
Solution: According to the report, the vendor issued a fix via CVS on August 15, 2003.

Title: Go2Call PC Dialer Can Be Crashed By Remote Users
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in Go2Call's PC Dialer.  A remote user can cause the application to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send some UDP packets that are 1500 bytes in length and contain, for example, 1472 'A' characters to UDP port 5000 to cause the dialer to crash.

A demonstration exploit is provided in the Source Message.
Impact': A remote user can cause the application to crash.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: (Vendor Confirms and Clarifies) Re: Mitel Voice Over IP Servers Disclose Calling Data to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mitel's voice over IP (VoIP) systems.  A remote user can obtain information about calls made via the system.
Acme reported that a remote user can connect to the target server's telnet port when a call is in place to gain information about the call in progress.

A remote user can attempt to login several times without success.  However, when an outside call arrives, the system will reportedly display information about the call.  Information provided includes the type of service, the extension number, and other call activity parameters, according to the report.

An exploit transcript is provided in the original advisory.  The original advisory is available (in Italian language) at:

http://olografix.org/acme/mitel.txt
Impact': A remote user on the internal network can obtain information about telephone calls on the system.
Solution:
The vendor has confirmed the flaw and is preparing a fix for an upcoming release.

The vendor has also clarified that a user must be on the internal network to connect to the device.

Title: Mitel Voice Over IP Servers Disclose Calling Data to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Mitel's voice over IP (VoIP) systems.  A remote user can obtain information about calls made via the system.
Acme reported that a remote user can connect to the target server's telnet port when a call is in place to gain information about the call in progress.

A remote user can attempt to login several times without success.  However, when an outside call arrives, the system will reportedly display information about the call.  Information provided includes the type of service, the extension number, and other call activity parameters, according to the report.

An exploit transcript is provided in the original advisory.  The original advisory is available (in Italian language) at:

http://olografix.org/acme/mitel.txt
Impact': A remote user can obtain information about telephone calls on the system.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Speek Freely Voice Communications Software Buffer Overflows Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the 'Speak Freely' secure voice communications software.  A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the system.  A local user may be able to gain elevated privileges.
Fozzy of the Hackademy reported that there are several stack buffer overflows.  A remote user can send a specially crafted UDP packet to the target system on the data port (2074) or the control port (2075) to cause the 'sfspeaker' application to crash or execute arbitrary code.  

The vendor notes that a remote user can send a VAT protocol packet with a user name longer than 256 bytes and, if showhosts is set, the name edit buffer will overflow.  A potential buffer overflow regarding the use of "face files" was also reported.

It is also reported that the software uses temporary files in an unsafe manner.  A local user can create a symbolic link from a temporary file name to a critical file on the system.  Then, when a target user executes Speak Freely, the linked file may be overwritten by Speak Freely with the privileges of the target user.  According to the report, arbitrary data can be written.  

The condition occurs when PGP key exchange is used, where the 'speaker.c' file creates an unsafe temporary file in '/tmp'.  According to the vendor, if the target user's umask() is set insecurely, the session key could be viewed by a local user.  The same type of race condition occurs in several other code locations, the vendor reports.

It is also reported that a replay feature (the fLoopback facility) can be exploited to send UDP packets to arbitrary hosts.  If the feature is enabled, the target system will send back the same UDP packet as was received to the source IP address of the UDP packet.  A remote user can spoof the source address, causing the target system to send the packet to an arbitrary (spoofed) IP address.
Impact':
A remote user can execute arbitrary code on the target system with the privileges of the user running Speak Freely.

A local user can cause files to be overwritten with arbitrary data with the privileges of the user running Speak Freely.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (7.6), available at:

http://www.fourmilab.ch/speakfree/

The author of the report indicates that the new version fixes "most" of the reported flaws.  No further details were provided about which flaws are not fixed.  However, the vendor reports that the fLoopback facility is retained in the new version.

Title: Auerswald COMsuite CTI ControlCenter Creates Back Door Operating System Account
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Auerswald's COMsuite CTI ControlCenter.  A "back door" operating system account is created by the software.
SySS GmbH reported that, during installation of the application, a user account "runasositron" is created with a common, guessable password.  A local or remote user could guess the password and gain access to the operating system.

The report did not indicate the privilege level assigned to this user account.
Impact': A remote user with knowledge of or the ability to guess the password can login using the "back door" user account [the password is reported to be easy to guess using password cracking tools].
Solution:
No vendor solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report indicates that, as a workaround, you can disable the "runasositron" user account.  According to the report, the vendor states that deactivating the account may disable fax/voice mail features if there is no user logged on.

Title: Columbia SIP User Agent (sipc) SIP Protocol Bugs Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Columbia Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) User Agent (sipc).  A remote user may be able to cause denial of service on the IP telephony management software.
The Oulu University Secure Programming Group (OUSPG) and CERT (CA-2003-06) reported vulnerabilities in implementations of the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), used for Voice over IP. OUSPG applied the PROTOS c07-sip test suite (http://www.ee.oulu.fi/research/ouspg/protos/testing/c07/sip/) against several vendor products to test the processing of the SIP INVITE message, used to set up sessions.

The vulnerabilities affect several vendor implementations. In general, the vulnerabilities may allow a remote user to gain access to the system or cause denial of service conditions. However, it is reported that for sipc, only denial of service conditions apply.

It is reported that sipc contains vulnerabilities in the processing of SIP INVITE messages.  A remote user can cause the sipc process to send responses to invalid addresses.  A remote user may also be able to cause sipc to hang by sending either fragmented or improperly formatted SIP INVITE messages to the target system.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions on the system.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (version 2.0, build 2003-02-21), available from kchin@sipcomm.com.

Title: iptel.org SIP Express Router SIP Protocol Bugs Let Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SIP Express Router from iptel.org.  A remote user may be able to cause denial of service on the router.
The Oulu  University  Secure  Programming  Group  (OUSPG) and CERT (CA-2003-06) reported vulnerabilities in implementations of the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), used for Voice over IP.  OUSPG applied the PROTOS c07-sip test suite (http://www.ee.oulu.fi/research/ouspg/protos/testing/c07/sip/) against several vendor products to test the processing of the SIP INVITE message, used to set up sessions.

The vulnerabilities affect several vendor implementations.  In general, the vulnerabilities may allow a remote user to gain access to the system or cause denial of service conditions.  However, it is reported that for the SIP Express Router, a remote user can trigger a segmentation fault, causing denial of service.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed, apparently composed of a new version (0.8.10) plus a patch.  The new version is available via CVS at:

http://developer.berlios.de/cvs/?group_id=480

The patch is available at:

http://www.iptel.org/ser/security/secalert-002-0_8_10.patch

Title: 3Com SuperStack 3 NBX and NBX 100 Telephony Systems Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending FTP Commands
Version(s): 4_1_4 and prior versions (using ftpd version 5.4 or 5.4.2 or possibly others)
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in 3Com's SuperStack 3 NBX and NBX 100 voice-over-IP telephony systems.  A remote user can crash the system.
A remote user can cause the system's FTP server to crash by sending the following type of command, with a string that is 2048 bytes in length:

CEL aaaa[...]aaaa

A remote user can disable the FTP server as well as the web-based administrative console and the call manager.  This will reportedly disable all calls.  According to the report, calls that are in progress at the time of the crash cannot be disconnected.

A hard reboot (power-cycle) is required to return the system to normal operations.

The underlying vulnerability resides in VxWorks 5.2 and 5.3.

SECNAP Network Security reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can crash the system.
Solution:
The vendor issued an updated advisory on July 7, 2006 indicating that a fix (Release 4.5) is available for the CS 1000 R2.0.

The Nortel advisory number is 2005006034.2.

The underlying vulnerability has been corrected in VxWorks 5.4 and later versions.

The Call Sever - SSC (Small System controller - Option 11C) and Call Sever based on CP3/CP4 (Motorola Processor), both of which use older versions of VxWorks, are still vulnerable.  The vendor indicates that the FTP server is only used for software upgrades and not for call processing and, therefore, represents a low risk in these older versions.

Title: (Cisco Media Gateway Controller OS is Affected) Re: Sun Solaris 'cachefsd' Cached NFS File System Daemon Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending RPC Requests Containing Invalid Procedure Calls
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A denial of service vulnerability was reported in the Sun Solaris 'cachefsd' cached NFS file system daemon.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions and may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system with root level privileges.
eSecurityOnline reported that cachefsd does not properly handle RPC requests that contain an invalid procedure call. A remote user can send a specially crafted RPC request to cause cachefsd to crash.  Sun has reported that a remote user may be able to execute arbitrary code with root privileges.

Cisco reports that the operating system shipped with Cisco Media Gateway Controller may be vulnerable.

Products running on Solaris 2.5.1 are reportedly vulnerable unless CSCOh013.pkg release 1.0(9) or later has been installed. The product that is based on this version of Solaris is Signaling Controller 2200 (SC2200).

Products running on Solaris 2.6 are reportedly vulnerable unless CSCOh013.pkg release 1.0(9) or later has been installed. Products running on Solaris 8 are vulnerable unless CSCOh013.pkg release 2.0(2) or later has been installed. The products that are based on these versions of Solaris are:

o SC2200 

o Cisco Virtual Switch Controller (VSC3000)

o Cisco PGW2200 Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) Gateway

o Cisco Billing and Management Server (BAMS)

o Cisco Voice Services Provisioning Tool (VSPT)

Cisco reports that the Media Gateway Controller itself is not vulnerable, but the underlying operating system supplied by Sun may be vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can cause the cachefsd daemon to crash.  A remote user may be able to cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system with root level privileges.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  Sun has issued the following workaround while a final resolution is pending:

Comment out cachefsd in /etc/inetd.conf as shown below:

For Solaris 2.6, 7 and 8:

#100235/1 tli rpc/tcp wait root /usr/lib/fs/cachefs/cachefsd  cachefsd

For Solaris 2.5.1:

#100235/1 stream rpc/tcp wait root /usr/lib/fs/cachefs/cachefsd  cachefsd            

Once the line is commented out either:

- reboot, or
- send a HUP signal to inetd(1M) and kill existing cachefsd processes, for example,
	  on Solaris 2.5.1 and 2.6 do the following:
		$ kill -HUP <PID of inetd>
		$ kill <PIDs of any cachefsd processes>

	  Solaris 7 and 8 do the following:
		$ pkill -HUP inetd
		$ pkill cachefsd                              

The possible side effects of the workaround are:

- for systems not using cachefs:

There is no impact.

- for systems using cachefs:

Only the "disconnectable" mount option is known to be affected by disabling cachefsd. This feature is rarely used outside of AutoClient and is undocumented.

The "disconnectable" option is specified at mount time using the usual mount syntax and is not enabled by default.

If cachefsd is disabled and the file server becomes unavailable then file systems mounted as "disconnectable" will not be reconnected when the service returns. For this reason we recommend that the "disconnectable" option is not used while cachefsd is disabled.

Mounts and unmounts should still succeed though an error message may be seen, e.g.

  mount -F cachefs: cachefsd is not running

There is no performance impact.


- for systems using AutoClient:

In addition to the advice given for systems using cachefs:

Only AutoClient systems using the "disconnectable" feature will be affected. Should the server become unavailable the root and /usr file systems will switch to disconnected mode as usual but will not be reconnected when the service returns. For this reason we recommend that the "disconnectable" option is not used with AutoClient while cachefsd is disabled on the client.

If cachefsd is disabled a warning message will appear during the boot of the AutoClient system:

WARNING: Timed out waiting for cachefs service to register

This indicates that the cachefsd service is not available which is as expected.

There is no performance impact.

Title: Cisco BTS 10200 Softswitch Underlying Operating System Contains Network Time Daemon (NTP) Buffer Overflow That May Allow a Remote User to Crash the Device or Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco's BTS 10200 Softswitch in the network time protocol (NTP) daemon provided by the Sun Solaris operating system. A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash or may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system. 
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the NTP daemon query processing functionality. A remote user can send a specially crafted NTP query packet to trigger a buffer overflow in the NTP daemon. 

Cisco reports that the following products are vulnerable:

All releases of Cisco IOS software 
Media Gateway Controller (MGC) and related products 
BTS 10200 
Cisco IP Manager 

[Editor's note: The underlying vulnerability in the NTP daemon code is the same as was reported for generic ntpd implementations way back in April 2001.]
Impact':
A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash or execute arbitrary code on the system.

[Editor's note:  Cisco states that "according to the available information, it seems that it is not possible to execute the arbitrary code."  Our information indicates the contrary -- that it may indeed be possible to execute arbitrary code.]
Solution:
The customers should install the latest Recommended Solaris Patch Cluster, available from:

http://sunsolve.Sun.COM/pub-cgi/show.pl?target=patches/patch-access

Also, customers should refer to the Cisco advisory:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/NTP-pub.shtml

Title: Cisco Media Gateway Controller (MGC) Product Line Underlying Operating System Contains Network Time Daemon (NTP) Buffer Overflow That May Allow a Remote User to Crash the Device
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): SC2200, VSC3000, PGW2200, Billing and Management Server (BAMS), and Voice Services Provisioning Tool (VSPT)
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco Media Gateway Controller (MGC) and related products in the network time protocol (NTP) daemon provided by the Sun Solaris operating system. A remote user may be able to cause the MGC system to crash or may be able to execute arbitrary code on the system.
The vulnerability reportedly exists in the NTP daemon query processing functionality. A remote user can send a specially crafted NTP query packet to trigger a buffer overflow in the NTP daemon. 

Cisco reports that the following products are vulnerable:

All releases of Cisco IOS software 
Media Gateway Controller (MGC) and related products 
BTS 10200 
Cisco IP Manager 

[Editor's note: It appears that the underlying vulnerability in the NTP daemon code is the same as was reported for generic ntpd implementations way back in April 2001.]
Impact':
A remote user may be able to cause the system to crash or execute arbitrary code on the system with root level privileges.

[Editor's note:  Cisco reports that, to the best of their knowledge, it is not possible to execute the arbitrary code.  However, our information, including information from Sun, contradicts Cisco's conclusion.]
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix.  More information is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/ntp-pub.shtml

For Solaris 2.5.1, Cisco reports that the patch has not been released by Sun.

For Solaris 2.6, the patch is available within the CSCOh007.pkg package. This package can be downloaded by registered users from:

http://www.cisco.com/cgi-bin/tablebuild.pl/mgc-sol 

For Solaris 2.8, the patch for this vulnerability is included on the installation disks and no further actions are needed.

Title: Cisco CallManager Affected by Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) Bugs
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Cisco reports that certain Cisco products, including the Cisco Call Manager, are affected by recently reported vulnerabilities in the Microsoft Internet Information Server (IIS) web server software.
These vulnerabilities were discovered and publicly announced by Microsoft in their Microsoft Security Bulletin MS02-018.   A remote user can cause the system to crash or cause arbitrary code to be executed on the system, potentially giving the remote user full access to the server.

All Cisco products and applications that are using Microsoft IIS are considered vulnerable.
Impact': A remote user can exploit flaws in the IIS web server to cause the web services to crash or potentially cause arbitrary code to be executed by the web server.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix for Cisco CallManager version 3.0, 3.1, and 3.2.  To upgrade, install win-OS-Upgrade.2000-1-3spA.exe, available from Cisco's Software Center.

Note that the fix carries through to all future releases.

Title: Cisco CallManager Memory Leak Lets Remote Users Cause the Server to Crash and Reload.
Description:
Cisco reported a denial of service vulnerability in their Cisco CallManager product.  A remote user can cause the CallManager server to crash and reboot.
It is reported that a memory leak in the Call Telephony Integration (CTI) Framework authentication process can cause the server to crash.  This can reportedly be triggered by a remote user that fails to properly authenticate when using CTI. 

Cisco notes that this is most commonly observed on CallManager systems immediately following the integration with an LDAP directory (e.g., Active Directory, Netscape). If the WebAttendant user, CTI Framework (CTIFW), has not been configured with a valid password in the customer directory, this can occur, regardless of whether the WebAttendant feature is actually used or not because the Telephony Call Dispatch (TCD) service is always enabled by default. 

Cisco states that the CCMAdmin->Global Directory and "Add a New User" configuration pages will stop working if the CTIFW user is not configured or if the CTI user's password is incorrect.  Apparently, other components such as the RIS Data Collector may also fail to function properly.

Cisco has assigned bug ID CSCdv28302 to this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause the CallManager server to crash and reload.  If this is performed repeatedly, a denial of service condtion can be created.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version, 3.1(2), available via the normal Cisco upgrade channels.  See the Source Message for details.

Title: Cisco Media Gateway Controller Underlying Operating System Flaws Let Remote Users Obtain Root Access
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Version(s): SC2200, VSC3000, PGW 2200, Billing and Management Server (BAMS), and Voice Services Provisioning Tool (VSPT)
Description:
Cisco issued a security advisory for their Media Gateway Controller application due to underlying vulnerabilities in the Solaris operating system.  A remote user can obtain root access on the server.
Cisco reported that customers using the Media Gateway Controller (MGC) product, which is installed on top of the Sun Solaris operating system, may be exposed due to security vulnerabilities in the default installation of Solaris.

The following products are affected:

SC2200, All systems running Solaris 2.6 (Through release 7.4(x)) 

VSC3000, All systems running Solaris 2.6 (Through release 9.1(x)) 

PGW 2200, All systems running Solaris 2.6 (Through release 9.1(x)) 

Billing and Management Server (BAMS), All systems running Solaris 2.6 

Voice Services Provisioning Tool (VSPT), All systems running Solaris 2.6
Impact': A remote user can exploit these vulnerabilities and compromise, control, and use the system for unauthorized purposes.
Solution:
Cisco has issued packages CSCOh007 and CSCOh013 to correct these vulnerabilities and harden the Solaris OS.  See the vendor's advisory for patch locations and directions:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/Solaris-for-MGC-pub.shtml
